--- title: "1.4 — Medieval Religious Writers — Class Content" execute: freeze: auto --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"} # Meeting Dates *Thursday, September 1, 2022* ::: ## Overview Today we discuss the Medieval writers. ## Readings ### Required Readings - St. Thomas Aquinas & skim *Summa Theologica* in *Reader* - Ch.2 (Early Preclassical Economic Thought) in Landreth & Colander Blaug unfortunately does not cover anything before mercantilism & the physiocrats. ### Recommended Readings: The following Wikipedia entries can also provide more background on these writers and their famous works: - [ Thomas Aquinas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Aquinas) - [ Ibn Khaldun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibn_Khaldun) - Al-Hamdi, 2006, [Ibn Khaldun: The Father of the Division of Labor](https://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.515.2885&rep=rep1&type=pdf) ### Questions to Help Your Reading - What topics does Aquinas cover in his writings? - What questions is he interested in? - What is his style of inquiry? - What does he say about whether prices are "just"? - What is his view on usury? - How does he engage with "the philosopher" (Aristotle)? ## Slides Below, you can find the slides in two formats. Clicking the image will bring you to the html version of the slides in a new tab. The lower button will allow you to download a PDF version of the slides. ::: callout-tip You can type h to see a special list of viewing options, and type o for an outline view of all the slides. ::: I suggest printing the slides beforehand and using them to take additional notes in class (*not everything* is in the slides)!
